                    					Plagiarism and Logic Self-Check
					
					By Tiptop Essay Research
on August 29, 2019
in Discussion
	
	            

	            
	            Home
Plagiarism and Logic Self-Chec...

	            
			

		

	




	
	
	
		
		
			
		
							
				 
				
								
				
Plagiarism
and Logic Self-Check



My personal experience with plagiarism and logic self-check proved to be of importance as it provided me with two useful results. In the initial draft of the research paper I wrote, I had inadvertently involved a fallacy in one of the primary arguments. I, therefore, used the fallacy of hominem so as to add more weight to the argument in the draft submission. As explained by Damer ( 2009), the fallacy of hominem occurs when an argument is not attacked directly, but the motive of the argument becomes the centre of focus.  However, an introduction to logic and syllogism(Plagiarism and Logic Self-Check) made me realize that reasoning and conclusion can be made in different ways and i therefore, focused on how an argument can be attacked. While documenting this piece of work and drafting, it, I realized from the plagiarism checker that almost half of my paper had similarity with some work from the internet. The plagiarism checker, however, informed that 58% of my work was original, and I had no need of having it reviewed. To have this mess corrected, I was forced to ensure that all the work was properly corrected according to their sources such that all the exact words that were used, found the corrected referencing against them as explained by (Neville).(Plagiarism and Logic Self-Check)




Works Cited



Damer, E, T. Attacking faulty
reasoning: a practical guide to fallacy-free arguments. Australia; Belmont,
CA: Wadsworth/Cengage Learning, 2009.



Neville, C. The complete guide to referencing and avoiding plagiarism. Maidenhead: Open University Press/McGraw-Hill, 2010.



 Culwin, F., & Lancaster, T. (2001). “Plagiarism, prevention, deterrence and detection”. Higher Education Academy.

^ Macdonald, R., & Carroll, J. (2006). Plagiarism—a complex issue requiring a holistic institutional approach. Assessment & Evaluation in Higher Education, 31(2), 233–245. doi:10.1080/02602930500262536

^ Bao, Jun-Peng; Malcolm, James A. (2006), “Text similarity in academic conference papers”, 2nd International Plagiarism Conference Proceedings (PDF), Northumbria University Press
^ Clough, Paul (2000), Plagiarism in natural and programming languages an overview of current tools and technologies (PDF)(Technical Report), Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield, archived from the original (PDF) on 18 August 2011
^ Culwin, Fintan; Lancaster, Thomas (2001), “Plagiarism issues for higher education” (PDF), Vine, 31 (2): 36–41, doi:10.1108/03055720010804005, archived from the original(PDF) on 5 April 2012
^ Lancaster, Thomas (2003), Effective and Efficient Plagiarism Detection (PhD Thesis), School of Computing, Information Systems and Mathematics South Bank University
^ Maurer, Hermann; Zaka, Bilal (2007), “Plagiarism – A Problem And How To Fight It”, Proceedings of World Conference on Educational Multimedia, Hypermedia and Telecommunications 2007, AACE, pp. 4451–4458
^ Youmans, Robert J. (November 2011). “Does the adoption of plagiarism-detection software in higher education reduce plagiarism?”. Studies in Higher Education. 36 (7): 749–761. doi:10.1080/03075079.2010.523457.
^ Jump up to:a b Hoad, Timothy; Zobel, Justin (2003), “Methods for Identifying Versioned and Plagiarised Documents” (PDF), Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology, 54 (3): 203–215, CiteSeerX 10.1.1.18.2680, doi:10.1002/asi.10170
